documents.document: Under a straight-forward reading of license a credible argument can be made that they do not. So hopefully OFAC can clear this up.
So here's the question: do sanctions no longer apply when a Russian entity is taking an action to comply with a request from the FSB?
In particular Art 15 of FSB code allows FSB to oblige other agencies (and private individuals in some cases) to tak… https://t.co/EeuX8wdDee
Which is a very broad universe of possible "transactions and activities" because the FSB's ability to require compliance is, um, very broad.
Why This All Matters: (a)(2) & (a)(3) can be read to remove sanctions from any activity incident to complying with the FSB in its duties.
where you'd expect to find (a)(1)'s "does not authorize acts for FSB's benefit" exception, if indeed it applies to… https://t.co/FEsyRCyACF
The rest of Gen Lic 1 is structured consistent with this. For instance, Para (b) is a more general list of things sanctions still apply to,
If "Note to Para (a)(1)" doesn't apply to (a)(2) or (a)(3), the license authorizes those transactions -- even if to, or on behalf of, FSB.
Which matters, because General License 1 also has an (a)(2) and an (a)(3), which eliminate sanctions for certain ot… https://t.co/8EBHlsxq5e
That note is by its terms a note to (a)(1) itself -- not a note to (a) as a whole, not to license as a whole, just… https://t.co/nmrbf0qmYP
Where I have concern is the drafting of the note to (a)(1), which provides that this does *not* permit activities that benefit FSB itself.
So General License 1 fixes this by authorizing payment of license processing fees, etc., to the FSB. That's all cool.
Fee isn't much (~$50), but goes to FSB bank account. Earlier sanctions made payment of this fee illegal, even where export was permitted.
FSB licenses some software (i.e. encryption, and the iPhones it comes in) which requires a modest administrative fee https://t.co/R9EtM6sj3T
Background: Gen Lic 1's intended purpose is some minor oversight patching up, to permit exports that the FSB has to issue licenses for.
But this isn't an area where you want drafting errors, and to me it is unclear how parts of the general license were intended to operate.
DISCLAIMER: to be very clear, what I'm suggesting here is a possible drafting error in Gen Lic 1's wording, not something done by design.
No, that OFAC general license didn't remove sanctions from FSB as was reported--but it does have some ambiguous language worth considering.
@ELforeignpolicy @Susan_Hennessey @rolltidebmz Seems so broadly worded though. Wonder how it interacts with Art 15 of FSB laws.

@JeanneBeanneS History will have to be the judge of that, though I think the insane context of how EO was drafted will weigh in her favor.
@EFavuzza @alexburnsNYT No, an attorney may not advance frivolous arguments. Very different from forcing the gov to prove its case.
@rumdood Her reference to surrogates and "after consideration of all the facts" make clear her concerns and they're constitutional in nature
@rumdood Who Constitution applies to isn't a weed, and Yates was clear: based on factual circumstances, she does not see basis to defend.
@Michael_Zak @thegarance Code does not nullify the Constitution; if Trump wants to argue he could exclude all non-whites, well, he can try.
@rumdood Religious disc. is unconstitutional; context shows Trump's goal was to ban Muslims, and the EO was his way of accomplishing that.
I agree that an AG should strive to uphold president's orders -- but here, Trump actively deprived AG of a non-frivolous basis for doing so.
Trump said he would ban Muslims; those behind the EO say it was intended to carry out that promise; and the EO dog whistles like a vuvuzela.
Against that backdrop, Yates couldn't find a good faith basis for arguing the EO was not unconstitutional, and I cannot fault her reasoning.
Trump's own campaign site still announces that he is "calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering… https://t.co/lwplXZO5Wh
